└── 1132756686119276544 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 💜 1
    When people talk about "capitalism" causing problems in the world, what they're really talking about is a very complex construct centered around marxist thinking on opressive systems stemming from market forces interacting with government collusion.https://t.co/Z0fTGrz8Wn
      [Quoting @ultimape: The desire to mass produce such addicting products run deep in our modern industrial world. The human need for bananas, driven by advertising campaigns and industrial mono-crops, means they too will soon be replaced.https://t.co/8ve5og6Emz]
    └── 1132757261523259392 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
        There are a number of mental frameworks centered around "capitalism", each flavor referencing it's own construct of what that means. Get two people in the room who decry capitalism or meme about post-capitalism and you're not likely to get the same answers. It's multifaceted.
        └── 1132758088442961926 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
            For some, "capitalism" represents Jeffersonian whiteness - often representing a disgust with how colonialism and male driven systems of rule leaked over from Europe as people reconstituted British law here in the states. It takes the same connotation as "white man's burden".
            └── 1132758607865556992 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                But for others it is more about racial boundary - with skin colour being a defining factor. The conflict arises when one group's language is referring to cultural moors and systems of rule, and another group is thinking about racial purity. There are groups viewing both as true.
                └── 1132759467035156480 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                    There is also hints of 'power' - how one group rules another with social forces (stuff like creeping gentrification, culture destroying social policing etc) end up swaying the way groups make meaning. Terms like 'violence' and 'oppression' are often framed under this ontology.
                    └── 1132760356303048704 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                        Like most conflicts among human groups, linguistic divide here seems to put a dampener on how things communicated. And there are also those who are smart enough to see this problem and intentionally muck with it via meta trolling. Most are simply blind to the schism in language.
                        └── 1132760947586674688 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                            Quite often I see people arguing at this language barrier. one person talking about racial stuff they likely learned in school, and another person arguing from the power / oppression framing. Like water and oil, they inevitably disagree and can't find common ground.
                            └── 1132761369525329920 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                When people talk about echo chambers, this language barrier issue is often hinted at but not fully spelled out. It's the same concept of the "shibboleth", but more fundamental. It's not just words differing, but entire mental constructed founded on divergences in life experience.
                                └── 1132761882845229058 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    Often even if two people or groups manage to hash out their differences in perspective on the issue (and find a common goal they both agree is worth persuing) we still see conflict. Each group's sense of risk varies, so choice of approach biases toward what they see as problems.
                                    ├── 1132762596115922945 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 💜 1
                                    │   A different way to think of this is thru a lens of story telling. We are raised in a society that fundamentally transmit's it's cultures wisdom thru narrative. Different people from different locations are brought up under widely varying 'myths' - epic tales that bias thinking.
                                    │   └── 1132763805459668993 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    │       I think of it in terms of children's books. Two different families living next to each other can be taught entirely different sets of lore. I was raised on Curious George + various forms of protestant. My best friend (when I was 4) had maylasian myths & where the wild things are.
                                    │       └── 1132764436190642178 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    │           Our belief systems differed quite a bit. But being so young, we didn't have enough of a language barrier built up to prevent us from mixing our myths together. Our stories cross pollinated and I still occasional think of spirits in terms of 'hauntu'.
                                    │           └── 1132765242100985856 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    │               This experience makes it easier for me to transition between different culture's way of thinking in much the same way that growing up bilingual changes the way your brain operates on language.
                                    │               └── 1132765568208130054 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    │                   I can 'think about' stuff like native american Spirit Animals in terms of hauntu, or see how Tsukumogami lore from Shinto influenced Walt Disney's Fantasia (but distorted thru the lens of western's view of magic)
                                    │                   └── 1132766610333294597 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 🔁 1
                                    │                       I have a framework I can hang these ideas on that others haven't spent time to develop. And it lets me model 'other' ways of thinking in familiar patterns. Effectively, I can translate a culture's lore (at least those that fit my internalized views) between ontological domains.
                                    │                       └── 1132767578395467776 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 💜 2
                                    │                           I see myths as foundations for concepts, similar to how language processing develops (or more specifically how what you 'hear' in a language is biased as a child develops). If mental framework isn't able to process other models for thinking, they might as well be speaking cat.
                                    │                           └── 1132767981728149509 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 
                                    │                               It's like how I can't roll r's when trying Spanish & I'll never be able to 'hear' languages that rely on inflection/intonation. If I was raised that way, I might have been able to. But it would take a lot of effort to put myself into the beginners mind to do that effectively.
                                    │                               └── 1132768803803344898 [2019-05-26] @ultimape 🔁 1
                                    │                                   I use this meta-model of understanding social constructs to great effect. Part of why I have all those weird poetry threads on here: trying to adapt my autistic brain to learn stuff like idioms and 'donkey anaphora'. Digesting metaphor from my own culture: https://t.co/qdbGAcD4ea

├── 1094686272155602944 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 425 🔁 96 💬 6
│   Twitter is a multiplayer real-time virtual world, primarily text-based with limited multimedia support. It combines elements of role-playing games, hack and slash, player versus player, interactive fiction, and online chat.
│   └── 1094687116796125186 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 193 🔁 10 💬 1
│       Players can read, view and contribute descriptions of objects, other players, non-player characters, and actions performed in the virtual world, as well as the “real” world. Players typically interact with each other by utilizing strings that resemble a natural language.
│       └── 1094688015199350785 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 192 🔁 20
│           While traditional MUDs typically implement RPGs set in distinct fantasy worlds populated by fictional races and monsters, with players choosing classes in order to gain specific skills or powers, Twitter allows every player to project their own fantasy and define their own game.
│           └── 1094689527615021056 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 276 🔁 29
│               The flexible nature of Twitter makes it difficult for any singular definition of “the game” to become canonical. Conflict between players with different interpretations of Twitter is a key feature of Twitter itself. Indeed, one of the most popular games is “hey, fuck that guy”.
│               └── 1094691177289281536 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 216 🔁 9 💬 1
│                   Unsurprisingly, few players put much thought into precisely defining the game that they are playing. Most players “pick it up” organically as they go along, inheriting the unwritten rules and norms of their peers via imitation and (limited) experimentation.
│                   └── 1094694093509128192 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 203 🔁 13 💬 1
│                       The key feature of (public) Twitter is that any player can interact with any other player. Any player can reply to any other player’s tweets, or retweet it, or quote-tweet it. This bypasses traditional limitations of both “real life” as well as older web mediums like “blogs”.
│                       └── 1094697463301079041 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 195 🔁 12
│                           Twitter is also searchable, and allows tweets to be “threaded” in chains. 
│                           
│                           This allows skilled players to build incredibly complex tapestries of hypertext, consisting of thousands of tweets.
│                           └── 1094698711618269184 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 210 🔁 13
│                               Why would such prolific players choose Twitter as a medium, rather than “websites” or “books”, which appear to be better suited to large volumes of content?
│                               
│                               Because Twitter allows any player to interact with any other player’s tweets.
│                               └── 1094699709027905545 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 398 🔁 38 💬 4
│                                   Most casual players do not appear to have caught on to the true potential utility of Twitter, or perhaps they are indifferent to it. 
│                                   
│                                   A web of tweets is a living entity that allows players to meet, interact and engage with 1000s of others *at the level of individual thoughts*.
│                                   └── 1094701060462075904 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 206 🔁 13
│                                       Properly constructed, a web of tweets allows you to:
│                                       
│                                       - witness how other players discover your tweets, via their patterns of Likes, RTs, QTs
│                                       
│                                       - connect each fragmented thought and experience into a part of a greater whole
│                                       
│                                       - recognise and embellish patterns in your own play
│                                       └── 1094701702807048197 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 169 🔁 8
│                                           We have not yet even begun talking about relationships. Players can build relationships with other players over time and shared interactions. Through cooperation, multiple players can share and merge webs with one another, helping each other find and share desired information
│                                           └── 1094702663864709121 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 206 🔁 14
│                                               Players observed to be “good” and “fun” have even been known to invite each other to meetups, offer each other jobs, become “friends” outside of Twitter. Twitter is a game with extremely real stakes and consequences, both good and bad.
│                                               └── 1094703313826664448 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 161 🔁 16
│                                                   You are not limited to a single identity or account on Twitter. A single individual can play as many different players simultaneously. You can invent entirely different identities and have radically different experiences with each.
│                                                   └── 1094704485912301568 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 139 🔁 10
│                                                       Any player can significantly improve their experience of Twitter by examining their own usage and evaluating it against their own desires and goals.
│                                                       └── 1094704815584595968 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 150 🔁 14
│                                                           At any moment, any player can completely change their experience of Twitter by deciding to play it differently.
│                                                           └── 1094705240614481920 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 229 🔁 23
│                                                               Who are you following? Why?
│                                                               
│                                                               What are you tweeting? Why?
│                                                               
│                                                               What experiences would you like to have? Why?
│                                                               
│                                                               Who would you like to play with? How? Why?
│                                                               └── 1094707087408390144 [2019-02-10] @visakanv 💜 248 🔁 28
│                                                                   With a little introspection, Twitter can be a tool for self-inquiry, making friends, testing ideas, messing around, finding information, practicing speech, and pretty much anything you like.
│                                                                   
│                                                                   It’s also, like everything else, just a game.
│                                                                   
│                                                                   Have fun!

            So let's talk about some of these features:
            Every tweet is public by default (you can still go private but it reduces the upside)
            People can limit who can reply, but usually they don't use it, so this means you can reply to almost everyone
            └── 1598395398300712960 [2022-12-01] @IaimforGOAT 
                Some people like to play status games, others refuse to play them.
                
                Sometimes these people will clash and this is good. Twitter is very good at surfacing inconvenient truths because of this, it also creates unnecessary drama. You can't have the good without the bad.
                └── 1598395400854962177 [2022-12-01] @IaimforGOAT

                    └── 1598395403258327040 [2022-12-01] @IaimforGOAT 
                        Due to the low friction in breaking the walls of the cluster of groups, twitter is considered the digital town square. I don't know any other social networks that does it as well.
                        └── 1598395405753950208 [2022-12-01] @IaimforGOAT 
                            This allows you to dip in several micro cultures / clusters of people, sometimes these are named but most of the times they aren't.

thinking about the long tweet meta. first, it’s a waste to write a tweet that’s only *slightly* long. people have to click an extra time to read the rest of a long tweet past the first 280 chars. so the game is to invite people to make the click

so the first 280 chars should be a good advertisement for the rest of the long tweet; it should promise the reader that something interesting is waiting, and then the rest of the long tweet should deliver on that promise. so no 300 character tweets unless somehow the last 20 characters are an amazing punchline; that’s not worth the extra click to your readers

second, a question any long tweet has to answer is: why isn’t this a thread? i personally have really enjoyed learning how to write threads well, it’s a distinct form of writing with its own distinct advantages. the key fact about threads, which i was introduced to by @visakanv’s twitter_rpg_strategy_guide.txt, is that any individual tweet in a thread can be RT’d or QT’d, by anyone, including yourself. (also that any individual tweet can itself be a QT!) 

what this means is that it’s worth learning how to write threads in such a way that every individual tweet stands somewhat on its own, and makes sense and says something comprehensible even when RT’d / QT’d outside the context of the rest of the thread. ideally (imo) each tweet in a thread should make exactly one point or introduce exactly one new idea - they get very cluttered if you try to say too much at once. the thread as a whole serves as a journey through the individual ideas or points in each tweet, and can also offer detours via QTs to other threads. one of the cool things learning how to thread like this does is that you can be surprised by which tweets in a thread resonate with other people - maybe you had a grand conclusion but it’s a throwaway tweet in the middle that people actually RT and QT and reply to. this is a level of granularity of feedback on your writing and ideas that longform doesn’t support by default (although google doc comments can be even more granular, eg) and i’ve learned a lot from it

from this perspective long tweets offer a return back to longform, but somewhat more casual longform than eg a ‘stack post. sometimes you wanna describe an idea that takes longer than 280 chars to meaningfully express. sometimes you wanna ramble and think out loud in a less structured way than a thread (this is what i’m doing rn). threads also have the disadvantage that if you do too good a job making the individual tweets stand alone then when they get RT’d and QT’d they may not even look like part of a thread, so people may not even click through to the rest of it. long tweets have the advantage (and disadvantage) that the whole thing is RT’d or QT’d at once, meaning it’s harder to single out individual bits but the whole package gets transported around twitter together, and unlike an external link it’s all still happening on twitter. typically when i write long threads the first tweet gets RT’d and QT’d the most and all the numbers drop off from there. so i’m interested in the ability of long tweets to preserve what might otherwise be a chopped-up thread as more of an organic whole. anyway that’s what i’ve got so far, time to get some food now. thanks for reading
